content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Gas Initial Concentration (<math alttext="Molar"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) <math alttext="H 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.030 <math alttext="I 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.015 <math alttext="H I"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="question mark"><mstyle><mrow><mo>?</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Samples of three gases, <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="I 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="H I gas"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, were combined in a rigid vessel. The initial concentrations of <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="I 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. (a) For the reaction of <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> and <math alttext="I 2 gas"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> to form <math alttext="H I gas"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI(</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the original value of the reaction quotient, <math alttext="Q sub c"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, was <math alttext="5.56"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>5.56</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> (before any reactions take place and before equilibrium is established). On the following graph, plot the points representing the initial concentrations of all three gases. Label each point with the formula of the gas.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Gas Initial Concentration (<math alttext="Molar"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) <math alttext="H 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.030 <math alttext="I 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.015 <math alttext="H I"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="question mark"><mstyle><mrow><mo>?</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Samples of three gases, <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="I 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="H I gas"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, were combined in a rigid vessel. The initial concentrations of <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="I 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. (a) For the reaction of <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> and <math alttext="I 2 gas"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> to form <math alttext="H I gas"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI(</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the original value of the reaction quotient, <math alttext="Q sub c"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, was <math alttext="5.56"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>5.56</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> (before any reactions take place and before equilibrium is established). On the following graph, plot the points representing the initial concentrations of all three gases. Label each point with the formula of the gas.

Equilibrium was established at a certain temperature according to the following chemical equation. <math alttext="H 2 gas, plus I 2 gas, is in equilibrium with 2 H I gas, delta H naught of reaction, equals negative 9.4 kilojoules per mole of reaction. K sub c equals 49"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HI</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="2.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>9.4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>;</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="1.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> After equilibrium was established, the concentration of <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was <math alttext="0.020 molar"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.020</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (b) On the graph above, carefully draw three curves, one for each of the three gases, starting from the initial points you drew in part (<math alttext="a"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). The curves must show how the concentration of each of the three gases changed as equilibrium was established.

<math alttext="H 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="I 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="H I gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are at equilibrium at a different temperature in a different vessel. (c) When the temperature of the equilibrium mixture is decreased, does the equilibrium shift to the right, favoring the product, or to the left, favoring the reactants? Justify your answer.

(d) Does the value of <math alttext="K sub c"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> increase, decrease, or remain the same when the temperature is decreased? Justify your answer based on the expression for <math alttext="K sub c"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the concentrations of the product and reactants.

(e) The following particle diagram represents the equilibrium mixture before the temperature is changed. In the empty box, draw an appropriate number of each type of molecule to represent a possible new equilibrium at the lower temperature.

skill.text: 3.A: Represent chemical phenomena using appropriate graphing techniques, including correct scale and units.
